dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_A
dialogue_turns.text: Okay, but wait. This article... it says, uh, 74% of Millennials anticipated leaving their jobs in the next three years? Like, what?
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Okay, but wait. This article... it says, uh, seventy four percent of Millennials anticipated leaving their jobs in the next three years? Like, what?
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: In 2019, well before the pandemic, a whopping 74% of Millennials anticipated leaving their jobs in the next three years.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_B
dialogue_turns.text: I know, right? That number just hits you!
dialogue_turns.tts_text: I know, right? That number just hits you!

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_A
dialogue_turns.text: But then it says, wait, that was before the pandemic.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: But then it says, wait, that was before the pandemic.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: In 2019, well before the pandemic, a whopping 74% of Millennials anticipated leaving their jobs in the next three years.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_B
dialogue_turns.text: Yes, exactly! That's the kicker! We always think this is, like, a new thing, but young people, they, uh, they've always had high turnover.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Yes, exactly! That's the kicker! We always think this is, like, a new thing, but young people, they, uh, they've always had high turnover.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: In general, young people have pretty high turnover rates, says Forsythe.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_A
dialogue_turns.text: But still, the market is just... it's wild right now. Five million Americans have left the job market altogether since the pandemic started.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: But still, the market is just... it's wild right now. Five million Americans have left the job market altogether since the pandemic started.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: The five million Americans who have left the job market altogether since the start of the pandemic, according to the Federal Reserve, are not counted in that figure.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_B
dialogue_turns.text: Five million! Can you even imagine? And they're not even counted in the unemployment rate.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Five million! Can you even imagine? And they're not even counted in the unemployment rate.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: The five million Americans who have left the job market altogether since the start of the pandemic, according to the Federal Reserve, are not counted in that figure.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_A
dialogue_turns.text: Right? So it's not just, like, people finding new jobs. It's people just... gone.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Right? So it's not just, like, people finding new jobs. It's people just... gone.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_B
dialogue_turns.text: Exactly! And it's for so many reasons, you know? Like, parents, uh, 1.4 million fewer mothers in the workforce.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Exactly! And it's for so many reasons, you know? Like, parents, uh, one point four million fewer mothers in the workforce.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: while there are now 1.4 million fewer mothers in the workforce than there were in early 2020.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_A
dialogue_turns.text: Oh my gosh, yes. And then people just, like, straight-up recalibrating their entire lives. Law school applications up twenty percent!
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Oh my gosh, yes. And then people just, like, straight-up recalibrating their entire lives. Law school applications up twenty percent!
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: Applications to law and medical school have jumped by 20% and 18% respectively, a sign that many are reconsidering career paths

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_B
dialogue_turns.text: Twenty percent! Medical school, too! It's like everyone suddenly decided, "Nah, this isn't for me."
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Twenty percent! Medical school, too! It's like everyone suddenly decided, Nah, this isn't for me.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: Applications to law and medical school have jumped by 20% and 18% respectively

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_A
dialogue_turns.text: And employers are, like, totally behind. They think they have months to figure out retention, but it's, uh, it's now.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: And employers are, like, totally behind. They think they have months to figure out retention, but it's, uh, it's now.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: Employers worrying about how theyll retain talent in a few months are already behindthey need to have it figured out now.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_B
dialogue_turns.text: Now! They're already behind. Studies show average workers are taking interviews weekly!
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Now! They're already behind. Studies show average workers are taking interviews weekly!

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_A
dialogue_turns.text: Weekly! It's not the normal dynamic. So companies need to step up, right? Like, Meta covering childcare for six months?
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Weekly! It's not the normal dynamic. So companies need to step up, right? Like, Meta covering childcare for six months?

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_B
dialogue_turns.text: Yes, exactly! Or Microsoft with permanent hybrid models. You can't just, like, expect people to come back to the old way.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Yes, exactly! Or Microsoft with permanent hybrid models. You can't just, like, expect people to come back to the old way.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: Microsoft and Salesforce, for example, are adopting permanent hybrid work models

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_A
dialogue_turns.text: No, because, um, people are literally quitting because of health risks in hospitality!
dialogue_turns.tts_text: No, because, um, people are literally quitting because of health risks in hospitality!
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: a good number of jobs, like those in the hospitality and restaurant industries, simply arent viable for everyone given the continued health risks of Covid-19.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_B
dialogue_turns.text: Right? And then the bonuses! Walmart with 2.8 billion in bonuses! They know it's cheaper than replacing people.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Right? And then the bonuses! Walmart with two point eight billion in bonuses! They know it's cheaper than replacing people.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: In December, Walmart announced that it would pay its 1.5 million retail workers another $700 million in cash bonuses, contributing to a yearly total of $2.8 billion.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_A
dialogue_turns.text: So it's like, uh, this isn't just a blip. This is a fundamental shift in how people view work.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: So it's like, uh, this isn't just a blip. This is a fundamental shift in how people view work.

dialogue_turns.text: Totally. The floodgates should be opening, but it's more like a total rearrangement of the whole damn riverbed.
